article_title: Technology will let us fully realize our humanity

passage_list.text: By the end of this decade, AI will likely surpass humans at all cognitive tasks, igniting the scientific revolution that futurists have long imagined. Digital scientists will have perfect memory of every research paper ever published and think a million times faster than we can. Our plodding progress in fields like robotics, nanotechnology, and genomics will become a sprint. Within the lifetimes of most people alive today, society will achieve radical material abundance, and medicine will conquer aging itself. But our destiny isn’t a hollow Jetsons future of gadgetry and pampered boredom. By freeing us from the struggle to meet the most basic needs, technology will serve our deepest human aspirations to learn, create, and connect.

This sounds fantastically utopian, but humans have made such a leap before. Our hunter-gatherer ancestors lived on a razor’s edge of precarity. Every winter was a battle with starvation. Violence or infection likely killed most people before age 30. The constant struggle to survive left little opportunity for invention or philosophy. But the discovery of agriculture afforded just enough stability to create a feedback loop. Material surplus meant some could develop skills that created even larger surpluses. In a blink of evolutionary time, civilization appeared—literature, law, science, engineering. While modern life can often feel like a rat race, to our paleolithic ancestors, we would seem to enjoy impossible abundance and freedom.

What will the next leap look like? One of the first shifts will be in learning. From the ancient Greeks through the Enlightenment, education’s primary goal was to nourish the mind and cultivate virtue. But the Industrial Revolution reframed education as training for economic success in an increasingly technical society. Today, kids are told from an early age that they have to study for instrumental reasons—to get into a good college, to get into a good grad school, to get a good job. All too often, this deadens their natural curiosity and love of learning.

As superhuman AI makes most goods and services so abundant as to be almost free, the need to structure our lives around jobs will fade away. We’ll then be free to learn for its own sake—nurturing the knowledge and wisdom that define our humanity. And learning itself will become vastly richer. Instead of just reading about Rome in dry text, you’ll be able to explore the Forum in virtual reality and debate an AI Cicero trained on the original’s speeches. Instead of getting lost in a crowded lecture hall, you’ll work one on one with a supremely patient digital tutor that’s been trained by the greatest teachers on Earth and knows exactly how you learn best.

AI tools will also supercharge your creativity. Today, expressing your artistic impulses requires both technical skill and resources—for films and games, sometimes hundreds of millions of dollars. These bottlenecks keep countless brilliant ideas trapped in people’s heads, and we are all poorer for it. But systems like Midjourney and Sora let us glimpse a different future. You’ll be able to speak a painting into being like a muse in Rembrandt’s ear. Or you’ll hum a tune and then work with a digital Wagner to orchestrate it into a symphony.

Thanks to this creative revolution, the coming medical breakthroughs won’t just offer longer lives but fuller ones, enriched by all the art, music, literature, film, and games created by humanity during those extra years. Most important, you’ll share all this with the people you love most. Imagine being healthy as you watch your great-grandchildren grow into adults! And material abundance will ease economic pressures and afford families the quality time together they’ve long yearned for.

This is the profound leap that awaits us—a future where our technological wonders don’t diminish our humanity but allow it to flourish.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?

options.A: AI will lead to boredom and gadget dependency
options.B: Technology will free humans to pursue aspirations like learning and creating
options.C: Scientific progress is currently too slow in fields like robotics
options.D: Medicine will only extend life spans without improving quality

questions.explanation: The passage argues that AI will achieve abundance and conquer aging, freeing humans from basic struggles to focus on learning, creating, and connecting, rather than leading to boredom.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the author's overall argument by noting contrasts, such as the rejection of a 'hollow Jetsons future' in favor of fulfilling human aspirations.

questions.question: As used in the passage, 'precarity' most nearly means
questions.explanation: The term describes the hunter-gatherers' life on a 'razor’s edge,' involving battles with starvation and early death, indicating instability.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use surrounding details, like struggles with starvation and violence, to infer the meaning of unfamiliar words.

questions.question: Which detail from the passage best supports the idea that historical education focused on personal development?

options.A: Education’s primary goal was to nourish the mind and cultivate virtue
options.B: The Industrial Revolution reframed education as training for economic success
options.C: Kids are told to study for instrumental reasons

questions.explanation: This detail directly contrasts ancient and Enlightenment education's focus on mind and virtue with modern instrumental approaches.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Select evidence that precisely matches the claim, avoiding details that describe shifts or consequences.

questions.question: The primary purpose of the examples about Rome and lecture halls is to

options.B: illustrate how AI will enhance learning experiences
options.C: argue for the elimination of jobs

questions.explanation: The examples show how AI will make learning richer through VR and personalized tutors, supporting the shift to learning for its own sake.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Determine purpose by linking examples to the broader argument, such as how technology transforms activities.

questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

AI tools will also supercharge your creativity. Today, expressing your artistic impulses requires both technical skill and resources—for films and games, sometimes hundreds of millions of dollars. These bottlenecks keep countless brilliant ideas trapped in people’s heads, and we are all poorer for it. ____ systems like Midjourney and Sora let us glimpse a different future.
questions.explanation: 'In addition' logically connects the current bottlenecks to the positive glimpse provided by AI systems, building on the idea of supercharging creativity.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Choose transitions that maintain the flow of ideas, considering whether the sentence adds, contrasts, or exemplifies.

questions.question: Based on the passage, the author would most likely agree that AI's impact on society will primarily

options.A: exacerbate existing inequalities in access to technology
options.B: enable humans to transcend survival constraints for self-actualization
options.C: lead to a decline in scientific innovation due to overreliance
options.D: prioritize economic growth over personal fulfillment

questions.explanation: The author infers that AI will free humans from basic needs, serving aspirations like learning and creating, implying transcendence for self-actualization.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For inferences, extend the author's logic beyond explicit statements, focusing on implied outcomes like freedom from struggles.

questions.question: The author's discussion of the agricultural revolution in this passage most closely parallels the projected AI revolution in Passage 1 in that both

options.A: create immediate abundance without any societal challenges
options.B: initiate feedback loops leading to rapid advancements in civilization
options.C: result in a return to simpler, less technological lifestyles
options.D: prioritize philosophical pursuits over material needs

questions.explanation: Both revolutions create surpluses that enable skills development and rapid progress, from civilization's appearance to AI-ignited scientific sprints.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify parallels by comparing core mechanisms, such as feedback loops, across passages.

questions.question: The student wants to convey that modern education diminishes intrinsic motivation. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.A: Historical education nourished the mind, but today it focuses on jobs, often deadening curiosity
options.B: The Industrial Revolution changed education to economic training, which is necessary for success
options.C: Kids study for colleges and jobs, making learning essential in a technical society
options.D: Ancient Greeks emphasized virtue, while Enlightenment thinkers focused on economic success

questions.question:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:
- Ancient Greeks to Enlightenment: education to nourish mind and cultivate virtue.
- Industrial Revolution: reframed as training for economic success.
- Today: study for instrumental reasons (college, grad school, job).
- Result: deadens natural curiosity and love of learning.
questions.explanation: This choice synthesizes the contrast between historical and modern education, emphasizing how the shift deadens curiosity.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Synthesize notes to support the goal by selecting and combining details that highlight contrasts or effects.

questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.A: Thanks to this creative revolution the coming medical breakthroughs
options.B: Thanks to this creative revolution; the coming medical breakthroughs
options.C: Thanks to this creative revolution. The coming medical breakthroughs
options.D: Thanks to this creative revolution, the coming medical breakthroughs

questions.question: ____ won’t just offer longer lives but fuller ones, enriched by all the art, music, literature, film, and games created by humanity during those extra years.
questions.explanation: A comma is needed after the introductory phrase 'Thanks to this creative revolution' to separate it from the independent clause.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recognize introductory phrases and use commas to set them off from the main clause for proper sentence structure.

questions.question: The author's use of analogies like 'a muse in Rembrandt’s ear' and 'a digital Wagner' primarily serves to

options.A: critique historical artists for lacking modern tools
options.B: emphasize the democratization of creative processes through AI
options.C: argue that AI will replace human artists entirely
options.D: highlight the financial costs of traditional art forms

questions.explanation: These analogies illustrate how AI will make advanced creativity accessible, removing bottlenecks and allowing ideas to flourish.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze rhetorical devices like analogies for their role in advancing the author's purpose, such as showing accessibility.
